column4: I don't know of any problem with gnome-terminal and keypad keys.  Are you saying that arrow keys remain in local mode instead of sending escape sequences to some applications?
I don't know what the exact problem is but with num lock off, pressing keypad 4, for example, moves the cursor to the left. In other terms, as I would like to have it, I get an escape sequence.
If you execute    tput smkx; cat -A; tput rmkx     You should see escape sequences from the arrow keys.  Do you?  And what does   echo $TERM   report?
(You type ctrl-d  to end that "cat -A".
xterm. I'll check those commands, one moment.
Yeah, there they are!
The reason I've run into this is that I want to hook those keys to macros, in a MUD client. By the by.
It seems that your client isn't using the terminfo sequence to ask for escape sequences.
But why does it work in aterm/xterm/whatever, and not gnome-terminal?
Perhaps the application is hardcoding some other method that doesn't match gnome-terminal.  The source code would know. ;-)
